title: Rashi on Berakhot
text: From what time do we read the shema at night? From the time that the Kohanim (priests) enter to eat their Trumah (holy food).     Kohanim that became defiled, and then immersed (in the mikvah), and the day has become night [resetting their purity], then they are allowed to eat Trumah.

UNTIL THE END OF THE FIRST WATCH-  A third of the night, as will be explained in the Gemara (p. 3a), and from then on the time has passed for it is not the time of lying down, and is not referred to in the words "Bishachbicha".  Also, before this period is not considered the time for lying down.  Therefore, if one read the Shema before, he does not fulfill his obligation.  If so, why do we read the Shema in the Synagogue?  In order to stand in Tefilah, in connection with words of Torah as is taught in the Briata in the Jerusalem Talmud Berachot.  Therefore one would have to read again after it gets dark.  [In this case] Reading the first section of the Shema at bed time suffices.
Until dawn - The entire night is called the time of laying down.
The Burning of the fats and limbs - Of the sacrifices that their blood is sprinkled during the day.
Their commandment - is to be brought the entire night and they do not become invalidated through "sleeping" until the morning star rises
Fats - of all (types) of sacrifices
Limbs - of a burnt offering
And all (offerings) which must be eaten that same day - for example sin offerings and guilt offerings and the lambs of atzeres and meal offerings and thanksgiving offerings
Their commandment - ie the allotted time for their being eaten

Until Dawn - And this is what brings them to become Nossar (leftover) as it says with the Todah Sacrifice "A person should not leave anything over until morning" and all of this is learnt from the Todah sacrifice.
If so why did the sages say until midnight - This is regarding Kerias Shema and eating Kodshim.

In order to distance a man from sin - And they are forbidden to eat before their time, in order that they should not come to eat them after dawn and therefore he would be liable to Kores. Similarly with reading the Shema, this is to encourage a person, so that he should not say "I still have time" and in the meantime it will get dawn and he would have missed the time. The offering of the fats that we learn here the sages did not say until midnight at all, and we did not learn here only to teach us that anything that is applied to at night is valid the entire night. Here also we learnt in a mishnah in the second chapter of Megillah. "The whole night is valid for reaping the omer and to offer up the fats and the limbs".
How is this possible - From where does the Tanna conclude the obligation to read Kerias Shema, that he began to ask here the time of reading?
On the text it is based - And there you can learn the obligation of reading (Shema)
If you want I can say - the reason we learn evening first is to learn it from the creation of the world.
It then taught about the morning - "From when can we read the shema in the morning".
From nightfall - This is when the sun has completely set as we learn later on.
Perhaps it means when the sun rises - the sun should shine on the 8th day and the man should make himself pure by bring his korban and then he can eat.
If so - that the possuk of "He will come pure" is a command, the possuk should say "Veyitoher", why does it say "Vetoher"?
There is no suspicion also- As we learned in a Mishna(Kiddushin 80b): but not with a woman and two men.
With two immoral- And it was taught there only with two who are known to be innocent(not immoral).
In their place- In a place where they appear frequently, we are concerned even with two people.
בדברא- in a field
"ואם תלמיד חכם הוא"- That he is consistently in his learning; reviewing his learning always, [then] that is enough.
"ירגיז יצר טוב"- That he makes a war with his Evil Inclination.
"ודומו סלה"- It is the day of silence, the day of death that is an eternal silence.
"זה מקרא"- This is Chumash. Which is a Mitzvah to read from the Torah.
"זו משנה"- That one should be engaged in Mishnah

"זה גמרא"- The reasoning behind the Mishnayos from there comes out [Halachic] rulings. However, one who learns [Halachic] rulings straight from Mishnah is called a ''destroyer of the world'' (Sotah 22a)
To slay the Damagers.
That it's discussing Krias Shema
He examined and did not find - he did not find a transgression that corresponded to all of this suffering.

Sufferings are chasttenings of love: God makes people suffer in the this world even if they are free of sin in order to increase their reward in the world to come - so that they will receive more than their actions merit.

This time I will thank G-d -Because she had Ruach Hakodesh(a holy vision) that Yaakov was going to have twelve tribes(through 12 sons), and he has four wives, so when she had her fourth son, she gave thanks because she got a greater portion than the original calculation she expected(on average each wife had three sons, and she had four).
It is written to afflict them- in the book of Samuel:
It is written to destroy them- in the book of Chronicles(Divrei hayamim 1:17):
I am not able- my strength has been taken away from me:
Complete his portions- of every Sabbath and Sabbath:
HE HID THE BOOK OF REMEDIES.  So that people would ask for compassion.
Ke'Hizra - [like] a staff in the hand of a person who strikes the staff downward in one motion (i.e. so the staff parallel to the ground).
Straightens (from the bow) Ke'Hivya - pleasantly, first his head, and the rest of his body afterwards, so his bow does not appear to be a burden upon him.
Ke'Hivya - like a snake that, when he straightens himself, lifts his head first, and then straightens himself gradually.
The Holy King - since during these days He shows his kingship to judge the world

The king of the Justice - like "King of Justice". Just as "the carriers of the ark of the covenant" is like "ark of the covenant". Another example is "the insets of the laver stands" which is like "insets of the laver stands". Similarly, "the valley of the corpses" is like "valley of the corpses".

The portion of tzitzit is recited during the recitation of the Shema, and even though the night is not a time for tzitzit, as it is written 'and you shall see it and remember,' we say it at night because of the Exodus from Egypt that occurred at that time.

I was appearing old, but I was not actually old, because a sign of gray hair appeared on me, on the day when Rabban Gamliel was removed from his position of leadership and Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah was appointed as the new leader, as is mentioned later in the chapter on the Morning Prayer (Berakhot 28a). On that day, Ben Zoma expounded upon the verse

Not that Jacob will be uprooted from its place -- Hark! We find that God calls him Jacob after this, on his descent into Egypt, as it says "God said to Israel . . . he said 'Jacob, Jacob,' and [Jacob] said "Here I am."
"Hark that I will do anew" -- before this, it is written "Do not commemorate the originals."

At the start he was patriarch to Aram -- to the men of his country, for he was from the land of Aram, as it is said "Across the river dwelt your forefathers," and he said, "unto Aram Naharayim [lit. Of the Rivers] until the city of Naḥor."
Patriarch of the whole world -- "Patriarch of multitudes of nations"
Sarai -- the singular form is "sarati" (Lamentations 1:1)
delineating his praises -- when he was originally selected, when his name was Abram: "And gave him his name Abraham."
Is reading the Law -- the section of K'riyas Sh'ma
And the time of reading arrives -- the time of K'riyas Sh'ma
in chapters -- between the breaks, and vita supra it differentiates in our Mishna between [the break between] the first chapter and the second and that between the second and the Sh'ma, etc.
Queries out of respect -- queries in greeting a man of honor, that it is appropriate to anticipate them in greeting [without first being greeted].
And responds -- greeting if he anticipated him, and in the Gemara it explains that if he queries, it is obvious he responds.
And in the middle -- in the middle of the blessing or the paragraph.
Out of fear -- a man who is afraid before them, that they do not kill him, but not on account of honor.
R"Y -- in the Gemara it is explained their dispute.
Between "He said" and "true and stalwart" do not break -- in the Gemara is explained their reason.
"And it will be that if you listen" our practice is both by day and by night -- for it discusses the teaching of Torah, for it is written: "and you will teach them to your sons."
"he said" our practice is only by day -- for it discusses the tzitzis, which our practice is only by day, for it is written: "And you will see them," to exclude the cover of night.
consecration of the day … a positive commandment that is time-determined:Remember the Sabbath Day to consecrated it (Exodus): Remember it using wine. (Pesachim 106a)
in keeping: of do not do labor. (ibid.)..

and these women, since they are included in keeping: As we learn (Kiddushin 29a): All negative commandments, whether time-determined or not, are obligatory for women, since Scripture equated the woman with the man regarding all Torah punishments.

A minor girl who was married off by her mother after her father's death, because from the Torah, her marriage is nothing, because a minor girl is not capable of legal decisions, and her mother does not have from the Torah the power to marry her off, but her father does, as it says "I have given my daughter to this man" (Dev. 22). And even so the Rabbis decreed marriage for her which requires refusal, so that he will marry her and she will not go out to immorality. Therefore if she refuses after a time and says "I cannot have him", she goes out and is permitted to any man, and does not require a divorce from him. And R' Yehuda ben Bava testified that there are times when it is a Mitzvah for Bais Din to teach her to refuse him, such as two brothers married to two orphaned sisters - one an adult and her marriage is from the Torah, and one a minor whose marriage is only Rabbinic. And the husband of the adult one dies without children, and she falls to her brother for Yibum. And it is found she (the adult sister) is connected to him from the Torah, and this connection forbids his wife (the minor sister) to him, because she is the sister of a woman connected to him (for Yibum), which is like the sister of his wife. And Rabbi Eliezer says in Maseches Yevamos (109a): "We teach such a minor girl to refuse her husband, and to uproot her marriage all the way back, and to make all her intimacy (with her husband) like immorality - to permit her husband to do Yibum with with her sister," as we learned in a Mishnah: "They may marry (a relative of) a raped or seduced girl" (Yevamos 97a). And Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava testified on the day Eduyos was taught that the Halacha is like Rabbi Eliezer.
And he did not interrupt the prayer of - That is to say, he did not make a break between Rabbi Yirmiyah and the wall in order to pass before him and sit in his place, rather he stood at his post.
Masters of the shields: Scholars who defeat each other in [questions of] law.
How can the living contradict the living: Perforce I need to admit that I said optional to him
The disseminator: Since he was standing in front of Rabban Gamliel and transmitting the lecture of Rabban Gamliel to the public.
Stop (lit., stand): Be quiet.

On Rosh HaShanah: In Tractate Rosh Hashanah (25a). As he said to him, "I decree against you that you shall come to me with your staff and with your money on the day on which Yom Kippur occurs according to your calculation."
Eshtakad: Last year.
Regarding the firstborn: In Tractate Bekhorot (36a).
With the incident of Rabbi Tzadok: It is in Bekhorot. Rabbi Tzadok had a first born; and Rabban Gamliel said to Rabbi Yehoshua, "Stand on your feet, etc.," like here.
Come and let us remove him: Come, and we shall remove him from the office of Nassi.
He was party to the incident: So there would be additional pain to Rabban Gamliel.
He lacks the merit of ancestors: And perhaps Rabban Gamliel would punish him.
They will remove you: They will take you down from the office of Nassi for the sake of another.

This is what we teach (the correct version): Perhaps they will remove you. He said to her, "[Let one use] an expensive goblet one day and let it break tomorrow." And we do not teach [the version that includes], "We elevate in sanctity."

An expensive goblet: An expensive glass cup called, arkia, in the language of Yishmael (Arabic). And people say in a popular parable, one day its owner can use it and be glorified by it; and [then] if it breaks, it breaks.
You have no white hair: You don't have white hair from old age, whereas it is becoming for a lecturer to be old.
Eighteen white rows: Eighteen rows of old age.
Rabban Gamliel was disheartened when he saw many students added that day; and he was worried, lest he be punished for having prevented them from coming in his days.
Filled with ashes: Meaning to say, these too are not worthy.
Pending in doubt, that they did not explain. From the increase of the students, the sharpness and analysis [of their study] grew.
The walls of his house were black: The walls of Rabbi Yehoshua's house were black.
That you are a pechami: One who makes coals (pechamim); and some say a blacksmith.
I insulted you: I spoke before you more than was appropriate.
The one who wears the uniform: The one who is accustomed to wearing the uniform shall wear the uniform; meaning to say, the one who is accustomed to the office of Nassi shall be Nassi.
One who sprinkles, son of one who sprinkles: A priest who is a son of a priest shall sprinkle purification waters.
Burnt ashes: Ashes burnt in ovens and in stoves; meaning to say, regular ashes.
Whose week was it: In Tractate Chagigah.
That student, who asked, "Is the evening prayer optional or mandatory," was Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai.
I have laid tefillin - And they are testimoney that I am under my creator's rulership and [in his] service.
You might ask for your needs- for example the brachot of אתה חונן until שומע תפילה and afterwards pray the first three brachot that are praise.
Need strengthening- That a person should always strengthen them with all his might.
The way of the land- If he is an artist, in his art. If he is a merchant, in his sales, and if he is a warrior, in his wars.
Olah- Like Olah offerings and sacrifices.
One who says... in his Tefillah.

Your mercy reaches the mother bird... [The Mishnah is referring to] men who present themselves as consciencious in deepening their entreaties to God by saying "you are merciful so that you even extend your mercy to the mother bird, as you command to send away the mother bird.
Promotes jealousy... by saying that God is concerned for these [birds] but not for his other creations.

His characteristics... His Mitzvoth.  He created his Mitzvoth not out of mercy but to place upon Israel the laws of his ordinances to make known that they are his servants and the keepers of his Mitzvoth and ordinances even in matters that give cause for Satan and idolators to reply to them saying, what need do you have for this Mitzvah.

Is called "olive:" And this would be "Who creates the fruit of *the fruit*" since the fruit is called "olive" and this is not a creation of heaven, since it is a creation by man's handiwork. But regarding the "vine,"  the "vine" is the tree and the grapes are the"fruit of the vine."

And Rav Huna said: What is taught, "He is permitted water and salt, but forbidden any other food and drink," could not be referring to one who says "Food is forbidden to me" because "food " only refers to the five species of grain: wheat, barley, spelt, oats and rye. Rather it refers to one who says, "Everything nourishing  is forbidden to me," and all things, granted they are not called "food" but they surely "nourish," except for water and salt. Therefore oil nourishes.

But [he who says omein] in "who builds Yerusholayim" - which is at the end of the blessings, then it is praiseworthy and so to at the end of the blessings of the recition of the shema, Shacharis and Ma'ariv. And that that the Borayso taught that [to say omein] after all his blessings is praiseworthy, it means to say: After all his blessings. And that that it taught that [to say omein] after all his blessings is derogatory, it means to say that [to say omein] after each blessings individually [is derogatory].
The small one with burned legs -- thus they called R. Zeira and the reason is explained in Bava M'tzia in "ha-Socher es ha-Po'alim" (BM 85b)
When it arrived time to mishrei -- from "shirusa," viz. to "break" the blessing of "The Extractor [of bread from the Land" and to eat.
R. Huna, that of Babylonia -- this is R. Huna of the s'tam, and because now R. Zeira is in the Land of Israel in place of R. Abahu. And it is Ullah from Babylonia saying this.
His effects -- lands
Close to the city -- that the master of the house can always see them, and know what they need.
Until where is the Zimmun blessing? -- that they need to be three, and when they are two they do not say it.

The Zimmun blessing is two and three -- at times they are two blessings; at times they are three. How so? When they are three is when they are three blessings and when they are two they are two blessings, as it is explained and goes on.
as he holds -- the Zimmun blessing until "The Feeder" and when they are two they do not say except the blessing of "the Land" and "Builder of Jerusalem."

And the one who said "three and four" -- when they are two, hark, they are three: "The Feeder" and the blessing of "the Land" and "Builder of Jerusalem." And when they are three, they add, blessing until "And of his good we live."

They establish for him -- We do not have this version. And this is our version: "And yet it was taught, "two and three in the blessing of laborers, who say the blessing of "the Land" and "Builder of Jerusalem" in one blessing. There is naught here but one blessing of "The Feeder" and the blessing of "the Land" and when they are three they add, "we bless" -- hark, three.
For Sir said -- supra, in two second chapter.
For hark he opens with "Blessed" -- and if it is Biblical, it is close to its fellow and we do not open with "Blessed."

As it was taught etc. there are of them etc. -- Like the blessings of fruits and commandments one opens and does not close, and the reason is explained in "Arv(ei) Pesahim" [Pesahim 105a] becausee all of them are one appreciation, and there is no break or other matter between, as there is in Kiddush.

And some of them close but do not open -- like a blessing which is close to its fellow which already opened. In the first blessing and the final blessing of the reading of Sh'ma, "True and stalwart" and "Truth and belief" that even though the reading of the Sh'ma breaks them up the blessings which were before rely on them, are for them "close to their  fellow."
Who is the good and makes good etc. -- which is not close to its fellow, which is not the blessing on victuals but on the grave of those killed at Beitar they mandated it.
For hark they were uprooting it in a house of morning -- according to R"A.
He doesn't learn Gemara, the Gemara is explaining the Mishnah, and the rabbis would gather and explain the Gemara, and an example is the Gemara that the Amoraim wrote
6 hundred thousand people

And he was accepting upon himself the yoke of Heaven: He was reciting the recitation of the Shema. From death, by Your hand, O Lord, from death: He should have died by Your hands, and not by the hands of flesh and blood.

This is explained in the Tosefta, that the Sages instituted the wording of "from the world and to the world" [in the blessings in the Beis Hamikdash] in order to teach that this world is nothing compared to the next world, it is as an anteroom before the banquet hall - meaning to say - become used to making blessings in this world, in order to be able to be normalized to the kind of existence that is in the next world, which is described as "totally extended."
Such was Avshalom (3rd son of David - to Ma'aka) who tried to take the kingship by force
